abstract: Martin Garbus is now an attorney of record in the child custody case concerning Mel Gibson and his former girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva. He represents Ms. Grigorieva.
snippet: Martin Garbus is now an attorney of record in the child custody case concerning Mel Gibson and his former girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva. He represents Ms. Grigorieva.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “I am now an attorney of record in the case.” So said Martin Garbus, in a brief phone conversation after a closed-door hearing Monday in the child custody dispute between Mel Gibson and his former girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva. Mr. Gibson’s lawyers had opposed a request by Mr. Garbus, who is from New York, to be allowed to represent Ms. Grigorieva in the Los Angeles County Superior Court case. They cited, among other things, his public remarks about the dispute during a November interview on one of Larry King’s final televised interview shows for CNN. On the program, Ms. Grigorieva described how she had recorded Mr. Gibson’s obscene rants to her because she feared he might kill her. Mr. Garbus, who appeared with her on the program, had said that Mr. Gibson did not want to pay any support for his daughter with Ms. Grigorieva.

headline.main: Mel Gibson’s Ex-Girlfriend  to Keep Her Lawyer

Janice Shade, True Body’s chief executive, feared that adding the line might alienate existing customers who are adamantly opposed to scented soaps, sometimes because of allergies. But the suggestion to add the scented soaps came from Ms. Shade’s North Atlantic region Whole Foods buyer, and Ms. Shade knew that a line extension would give her company the larger shelf presence it needed to increase sales, which were about $45,000 in 2009.

abstract: The special treatment of derivatives in bankruptcy can interfere with the use of Chapter 11 to resolve cases involving nonbank financial institutions.
snippet: The special treatment of derivatives in bankruptcy can interfere with the use of Chapter 11 to resolve cases involving nonbank financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: As I have noted before on DealBook, derivative contracts have a broad exception to the normal rules of bankruptcy, often called a safe harbor. Derivatives are not subject to the automatic stay, collateral collected on the eve of bankruptcy cannot be attacked as a preference, and derivative contracts are not subject to a debtor’s ability to assume or reject contracts unless the nondebtor counterparty consents.

headline.main: Safe Harbors for Derivatives vs. Chapter 11

lead_paragraph: Opponents of the health law sometimes like to suggest that cutting health costs would be easy, if only we’d be willing to try common-sense ideas. But that’s wishful thinking. The law does include most of the common-sense ideas supported by health economists ranging from Mark McClellan (the former Bush administration official) to David Cutler (a former Clinton and Obama adviser). There’s just no getting around the fact that reducing the growth rate of health costs will be difficult.

headline.main: Wishful Thinking on Health Costs

lead_paragraph: 3 Crisis Reports Coming Heidi N. Moore, during her DealBook stint, once likened a paper by some Republican members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission to “a game of political Rashomon.” But as Jeremy Irons, playing Claus von Bulow, drawled in “Reversal of Fortune,” “You have no idea.” For come Thursday, we will be getting not just two views of the financial crisis, but three. abstract: CBS, Warner Brothers Television and the show’s executive producer, Chuck Lorre, said, “We are profoundly concerned for his health and well-being, and support his decision.”

lead_paragraph: Dave Itzkoff and Bill Carter write about CBS and Warner Brothers Television’s announcement on Friday that their sitcom “Two and a Half Men” would take a production hiatus, as co-star Charlie Sheen enters a rehabilitation center. In a brief statement issued by the network and the studio, as well as Chuck Lorre, the comedy’s creator and executive producer, they said, “We are profoundly concerned for his health and well-being, and support his decision.” The statement did not disclose the reason for Mr. Sheen’s entering rehab. On Thursday, the actor was taken by ambulance to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. His publicist said at the time that Mr. Sheen had severe abdominal pains resulting from a hernia condition, and a friend of the actor’s said he had been laughing too hard at a television show.

headline.main: From ArtsBeat: ‘Two and a Half Men’ on Hiatus

abstract: The Chevron Corporation reported fourth-quarter sales and refining profits that failed to meet analysts’ estimates on Friday.
snippet: The Chevron Corporation reported fourth-quarter sales and refining profits that failed to meet analysts’ estimates on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Chevron Corporation reported fourth-quarter sales and refining profits that failed to meet analysts’ estimates on Friday. Chevron said profit rose to $5.3 billion, or $2.64 a share, compared with $3.07 billion, or $1.53 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $54.03 billion, from $48.68 billion, but fell short of the $58.8 billion analysts had expected. The company’s refineries in the United States performed “worse than expected,” contributing less to the bottom line than anticipated, said Paul Cheng, an analyst in New York at Barclays. Profit in Chevron’s worldwide oil- and gas-production business rose 16 percent, to $4.85 billion, compared with a year earlier, the company said. Earnings from the unit’s operations in the United States fell 13 percent, to $930 million.

headline.main: Chevron Reports Disappointing Sales

lead_paragraph: SIZE is the enemy of growth. It is one of the unwritten laws of business, a matter of simple percentages. After all, when a company has $1 billion in yearly sales, an extra $1 billion doubles its size. Add $1 billion in new business to a $10 billion-a-year company, and it amounts to just 10 percent growth. The size-growth tradeoff seems inevitable, an inescapable force like gravity.

headline.main: The Power of the Platform at Apple

snippet: Joshua Last, sales manager of GlobeTask, a virtual assistance company based in Jerusalem, elicited a deep question when he tried to get frozen hot dogs into Israel.
lead_paragraph: OUR team at GlobeTask in Jerusalem is very tight. I was born in Detroit, and most of my colleagues are Americans, too.

headline.main: Bringing the Fourth of July to Israel
headline.print_headline: With Hot Dogs and Grill, The Fourth of July Arrives in Israel

abstract: Major oil companies are spending billions on projects now, and investors could reap some of the benefits in several years.
snippet: Major oil companies are spending billions on projects now, and investors could reap some of the benefits in several years.
lead_paragraph: Major oil firms have become big spenders. Together, the top three American giants say they plan capital spending this year of about $60 billion, well above the year of peak crude prices in 2008, despite showing only tepid cash flow growth. At first blush, this looks like desperation, as Western oil companies increasingly struggle to replace crude reserves. But patient investors will find higher returns are on the way.

headline.main: Likely Upswing in the Oil Patch
headline.print_headline:
Patience Pays
In the Oil Patch

byline.original: By Christopher Swann and Agnes T. Crane

abstract: Ash Williams, who runs the $150 billion Florida pension fund, offered important advice to managers hoping to win his business: do your homework.
snippet: Ash Williams, who runs the $150 billion Florida pension fund, offered important advice to managers hoping to win his business: do your homework.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Ash Williams, the hedge fund manager turned pension titan, has a host of suggestions for those firms hoping to land some big pension money. His most important advice: do your homework.

headline.main: How a Hedge Fund Can Land a Whale

abstract: Brian T. Moynihan is to receive a $9.05 million stock bonus on top of his $950,000 base salary, despite the bank’s lackluster 2010.

abstract: Chemicals used in a process called fracking contaminate water sources, Congressional investigators told the E.P.A.
snippet: Chemicals used in a process called fracking contaminate water sources, Congressional investigators told the E.P.A.
lead_paragraph: Oil and gas service companies injected tens of millions of gallons of diesel fuel into onshore wells in more than a dozen states from 2005 to 2009, Congressional investigators have charged. Those injections appear to have violated the Safe Water Drinking Act, the investigators said in a letter to the Environmental Protection Agency on Monday.

headline.main: Gas Drilling Technique Is Labeled Violation
headline.print_headline: A Gas Drilling Technique Is Labeled a Violation
